tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the percentage of weight supported by the central cable. It involves understanding the relationship between Young's modulus, area, length, and force (weight) in the context of multiple cables. It requires multiple steps to solve for the forces in each cable and then calculate the percentage. It integrates concepts from mechanics of materials.

answer_validation.reasoning: All three cables have identical length and cross-sectional area, but different Young\'s moduli: the central steel cable has modulus 3E, while the two outer aluminium cables have modulus E. Because the slab is rigid and horizontal, all three attachment points undergo the same vertical displacement. Thus the three cables are in parallel under a common deformation (iso-strain condition). For a bar in axial loading, stiffness is $k = \dfrac{EA}{L}$. With same $A$ and $L$, stiffness is proportional to $E$. Hence: $k_1 = E$, $k_2 = 3E$, $k_3 = E$. The total stiffness is $k_{\text{tot}} = E + 3E + E = 5E$. Load in each cable is proportional to its stiffness: $P_i = k_i \dfrac{\delta}{L}$, so $P_2 / W = k_2 / k_{\text{tot}} = 3E / 5E = 3/5 = 0.6$. Therefore the central cable carries 60% of the total weight W. This matches the official answer range 60 to 60.

step_by_step: Identify that the slab is rigid and remains horizontal, so all three suspension points move by the same vertical displacement when loaded.

Recognize that each cable behaves as an axial spring with stiffness $k = \dfrac{EA}{L}$. Since all cables have the same length and cross-sectional area, their stiffnesses are proportional only to their Young\'s moduli.
Assign stiffnesses: for each aluminium cable, $k_A \propto E$; for the central steel cable, $k_S \propto 3E$. Thus $k_1 = E$, $k_2 = 3E$, $k_3 = E$ in relative terms.

Because the cables are in parallel under a common displacement, the load in each cable is proportional to its stiffness: $P_i = k_i \delta$ (with the same $\delta$ for all). Therefore, the fraction of the total load carried by cable i is $P_i/W = k_i / (k_1 + k_2 + k_3)$.
Compute the total relative stiffness: $k_{\text{tot}} = E + 3E + E = 5E$. The central cable\'s share is $k_2 / k_{\text{tot}} = 3E / 5E = 3/5 = 0.6$.

topic.name: Axial loading and composite/parallel bars
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 1: Structures -> Stress and strain, axial members, statically indeterminate and composite bars

concepts.name: Load sharing in parallel members (iso-strain condition)
Rigid body and compatibility of deformations

essential: Concept of Young\'s modulus and Hooke\'s law in axial loading
Idea of stiffness $k$ as force per unit displacement
Compatibility of deformations in rigid-body supported systems
helpful: Understanding of composite bars under axial load (iso-strain vs iso-stress)
Basic statics: total reaction equals total applied load

Main Concept: requires: Concept of Young\'s modulus and Hooke\'s law in axial loading
requires: Compatibility of deformations in rigid-body supported systems
enables: Analysis of load distribution in multi-material support systems
enables: Design of efficient suspension and support structures with mixed materials

difficulty_factors: Requires recognizing that the slab is rigid so all cables have equal extension
Needs understanding that load sharing is proportional to stiffness, not modulus alone unless area and length are equal

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Simple Elastic Members in Tension and Compression
textbook_references.text_snippet: The load distribution is proportional to the relative axial rigidity of the components: $P_i = P_{total} (E_i A_i)/(\sum E_j A_j)$.

video_references.topic_covered: Equivalent Young\'s modulus and load sharing in compound bars under axial loading

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Model cables as axial springs -> Use compatibility (equal extension) -> Express forces via stiffness -> Apply total load equilibrium -> Compute load fraction for central cable -> Convert to percentage
key_insights: Because the slab is rigid, all cables have the same extension, so the system is an iso-strain composite in parallel.
With equal length and area, stiffness ratios are simply the ratios of Young\'s moduli.
Load in each parallel member is proportional to its stiffness.

formulas_principles.name: Axial deformation of a prismatic bar
formulas_principles.conditions: Linear elastic material, uniform cross-section, uniaxial loading
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to relate force and extension in each cable and to define stiffness.

formulas_principles.name: Axial stiffness of a bar
formulas_principles.conditions: Derived from Hooke\'s law for axial members
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation to compare stiffness of steel and aluminium cables.

formulas_principles.name: Load fraction in parallel springs
formulas_principles.conditions: Members in parallel with common displacement
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly gives the share of total weight carried by each cable.

industry_examples: Design of multi-material hanger systems in aircraft interiors where different cables or rods share loads according to stiffness.
Suspension of equipment or payloads using mixed-material cables where weight and stiffness optimization is required.
specific_systems: Support rods and tie-bars in aircraft fuselage frames that may use different alloys but must share loads predictably.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding how load is shared among supports of different stiffness is crucial to avoid overloading a stiffer member, which could lead to premature failure even when the average load seems safe.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming the weight is shared equally among the three cables (each taking W/3) without considering stiffness differences.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus only on symmetry in geometry and forget that material properties affect load sharing.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always check whether supports have the same stiffness. If not, compute stiffness and use it to distribute load.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives 33% instead of 60%, a large error.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using Young\'s modulus ratios directly as load ratios without confirming that areas and lengths are identical.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They memorize a shortcut (load proportional to E) without its assumptions.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember the general relation: load share is proportional to $EA/L$. Only reduce to E when A and L are the same.
common_mistakes.consequence: Can lead to wrong answers in problems where areas or lengths differ.

common_mistakes.mistake: Treating the three cables as being in series instead of in parallel, leading to equal forces instead of equal deformations.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between series and parallel composite bar models.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Visualize load path: if members are side-by-side between same two rigid bodies, they are in parallel (same deformation).

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: P for Parallel, P for same Pull (displacement); S for Series, S for same Stress (force).
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that parallel members share deformation (iso-strain) while series members share force (iso-stress).
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when deciding how to model composite bars or multiple supports.

flashcards.front: For several bars connecting the same two rigid plates and loaded axially, what is common: force or deformation?
flashcards.back: Deformation (axial extension) is common. The bars are in parallel, so they all undergo the same displacement but carry different forces depending on stiffness.

flashcards.front: Write the axial stiffness k of a prismatic bar of length L, area A, and Young\'s modulus E.
Three parallel bars have stiffnesses k, 2k, and 3k. What fraction of the total load is carried by the 3k bar?
flashcards.back: Total stiffness = k + 2k + 3k = 6k. Fraction for 3k bar = $3k/6k = 1/2 = 50\%$.

flashcards.front: When can you say load share is proportional only to E in a composite bar?
flashcards.back: Only when all members have the same length and cross-sectional area, so stiffness $k = EA/L$ differs only by E.

real_world_context.application: Suspension of heavy equipment using multiple cables of different materials.
real_world_context.industry_example: In an aircraft hangar, a heavy inspection platform may be hung using both steel and aluminium rods. Engineers must calculate how much load each rod carries to ensure none exceeds its allowable stress.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: If the stiffer rod is overloaded due to incorrect assumptions of equal sharing, it may fail suddenly, causing safety hazards and structural damage.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Notice that only stiffness ratios are needed. If lengths and areas are same, just use modulus ratios to get load fractions quickly.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If one member is significantly stiffer and geometry is symmetric, expect it to carry more than an equal share; choose the option with higher percentage for the stiffer member.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes: 1 minute to set up stiffness ratios and 1 minute to compute and check the percentage.

search_keywords: GATE AE structures composite bar problem
rigid slab supported by multiple rods

alternative_methods.name: Direct deformation compatibility with forces
alternative_methods.description: Assume unknown forces $P_1, P_2, P_3$ in each cable. Use $\delta_1 = \delta_2 = \delta_3$ with $\delta_i = P_i L/(E_i A)$ to relate the forces, then apply equilibrium $P_1 + P_2 + P_3 = W$ to solve for each $P_i$.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Follows first principles and works even when lengths or areas differ. Cons: Slightly more algebra than using stiffness ratios.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When cables have different lengths or cross-sectional areas, or when you want a full derivation from basics.

connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Mechanics: Similar to distributing load among parallel springs in basic mechanics, reinforcing the idea of stiffness and compatibility.
connections_to_other_subjects.Materials Science: Young\'s modulus reflects material stiffness, connecting microscopic bonding to macroscopic structural behavior.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structural Analysis: Conceptually related to statically indeterminate structures where compatibility conditions are needed to find reactions.

deeper_dive_topics: Analysis of statically indeterminate beams and frames using force and displacement methods
Design of composite members with tailored stiffness for vibration control
Nonlinear behavior of cables and large deflection effects

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Stress and strain; axial members; statically indeterminate and composite bars
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent conceptual question linking composite bar theory with a simple structural support scenario; well aligned with axial loading and compatibility topics.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided related examples of composite bars and load distribution based on axial rigidity (Megson, Harsha lecture). While not exactly the same geometry, the principles of iso-strain condition and load sharing proportional to EA were directly applicable. Some other chunks about wing trusses and open sections were not relevant.

future_questions_potential: Modify the problem so that the central cable has a different length or cross-sectional area and ask for the new load distribution.
Ask for the actual extension of the cables given numerical values of W, A, L, and E.
Replace the rigid slab with a flexible beam and ask for reactions using beam deflection compatibility.
Introduce allowable stresses for steel and aluminium and ask whether the design is safe under the given load.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: As shown in the figure, a rigid slab CD of weight W (distributed uniformly along its length) is hung from a ceiling using three cables of identical length and cross-sectional area. The central cable is made of steel (Young’s modulus = 3E) and the other two cables are made of aluminium (Young’s modulus = E). The percentage of the total weight taken by the central cable is ______ % (round off to the nearest integer).
